heroDescription: Cloud Accounting • 4.6M Subscribers • NZ$2.10B Revenue • AI Sell-Off Target
heroCompanyDescription: Xero Limited (ASX: XRO) is a New Zealand-founded, ASX-listed cloud accounting platform serving 4.6 million subscribers globally. The stock has become ground zero for the AI disruption repricing of SaaS — down 60% from its A$194 high to A$78.50, with the ASX tech sector collapsing 9.4% in a single session triggered by AI capability demonstrations (Anthropic Claude specifically cited as catalyst). Analyst consensus remains unanimously Buy with an average target of A$191, representing 143% upside. Either the market is right and AI will structurally impair cloud accounting, or this is the widest dislocation between price and fundamentals in Xero's listed history.

skew.rationale: The sell-off has now reached 60% on zero evidence of actual churn, customer loss, or revenue deceleration. Every analyst rates Buy. AI disruption fears are legitimate as a long-term structural question, but the market is pricing terminal impairment of a business that just delivered 20% revenue growth, historic low churn, and Rule of 40 at 44.5%. At A$78.50, the risk-reward skews decisively upside — unless AI displaces accounting software faster than any technology transition in history.

verdict.text: Xero has become the defining test case for the AI-disrupts-SaaS thesis. The stock is down 60% from its highs — an acceleration from the 55% decline just weeks ago — after an ASX tech sector rout triggered by Anthropic's Claude AI demonstrations that the market interpreted as threatening to cloud accounting moats. But here are the facts: revenue grew 20%, ARPU grew 15%, churn is at historic lows, Rule of 40 is 44.5%, and all 15 covering analysts rate Buy with an average target of A$191 (143% upside). The Melio B2B payments acquisition is approaching breakeven 6-12 months ahead of schedule. The gap between what the business is doing and what the market is pricing has never been wider. This is either the opportunity of the cycle or the market correctly front-running a paradigm shift that hasn't yet appeared in any metric.

featuredRationale: AI disruption sell-off deepens to -60%. Anthropic Claude demo triggered ASX tech rout. Zero churn evidence. All 15 analysts Buy at avg A$191 (143% upside). Widest price-vs-fundamentals gap in Xero history.

rows: Anthropic Claude demo; ASX IT Index -9.4%
identity.overview: New Zealand-headquartered cloud accounting platform serving 4.6 million subscribers globally. Stock down 60% in 8 months as AI disruption fears rip through the SaaS sector — Anthropic's Claude AI was specifically cited as a catalyst for the February 2026 tech rout that saw the ASX IT Index fall 9.4% in one session. Despite the sell-off, the business is executing: revenue +20%, ARPU +15%, Rule of 40 at 44.5%, churn at historic lows. Melio B2B payments acquisition (US$2.5B) approaching breakeven 6-12 months ahead of plan. Xero argues its moat lies in domain expertise, decades of accounting data, regulatory compliance, payment rails, and a 1,000+ app ecosystem that AI cannot replicate overnight.

hypotheses.title: D1: Platform Expansion Delivers
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↓ Execution flawless but market continues repricing
hypotheses.description: Xero's execution is among the strongest on the ASX: 20%+ revenue growth, ARPU +15%, Rule of 40 at 44.5%, churn at historic lows, subscriber additions positive across all geographies. The platform expansion strategy is working by every measurable metric. But the market is pricing none of it. The stock is down 60% from A$194 despite delivering four consecutive earnings beats. All 15 covering analysts rate Buy with an average target of A$191 (143% upside from A$78.50). The dislocation between price and fundamentals has never been wider in Xero's history.
requires: FY26 revenue growth sustained at 18%+ (currently tracking +20%)
Subscriber churn remains at or below historic lows
AI monetisation strategy articulated for FY27 (Xero as AI beneficiary, not victim)
supporting: Financial Statements: 1H FY26 beat on all metrics; Rule of 40 at 44.5%; four consecutive earnings beats ignored by market
Broker Research: All 15 analysts Buy/Outperform; UBS A$174, Citi A$210, Macquarie A$229, Ord Minnett A$200; avg A$191
Academic: SaaS switching costs highest in accounting category; AI augments, not replaces, compliance workflows
Corporate Comms: AI monetisation strategy planned for FY27; Xero argues domain expertise and data moat
Competitor Data: No competitor taking material share; QuickBooks growth in tax/mid-market, not SMB cloud
Alternative Data: App downloads stable; hiring consistent with growth; no churn signal in any third-party data
Economic: Cloud accounting penetration below 50%; secular digitisation tailwind intact
Melio: B2B payments reaching breakeven H2 FY28, 6-12 months ahead of plan; US market wedge gaining traction
contradicting: Market price: A 60% drawdown sustained over 8 months is the single most powerful contradicting evidence. The aggregated judgment of every market participant says this business is worth 60% less than 8 months ago
Capital flows: Growth fund exodus (Hyperion, Baillie Gifford reducing); short interest elevated at 4-5%

hypotheses.title: D2: Melio Integration Succeeds
hypotheses.statusText: Evidence Emerging — Breakeven Ahead of Plan
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↑ Melio breakeven H2 FY28, 6-12 months ahead of plan
hypotheses.description: The US$2.5B Melio acquisition is showing signs of working. Management disclosed that Melio is tracking toward breakeven by H2 FY28, 6-12 months ahead of the original plan. B2B payments are becoming the wedge product for US SMB market penetration. The payments+accounting bundle creates a competitive proposition that QuickBooks cannot match on payments and PayPal cannot match on accounting. At current depressed valuations, the market is assigning near-zero value to Melio — any evidence of integration success represents pure upside optionality.
requires: Melio breakeven confirmed by H2 FY28 (currently tracking ahead)
US subscriber count growth acceleration from Melio cross-sell
Melio revenue contribution visible and growing in FY26-27 results
No integration issues, write-downs, or management distraction
supporting: Corporate Comms: Melio breakeven H2 FY28, 6-12 months ahead of original timeline
Strategic logic: Payments is the missing piece in Xero's US go-to-market; no other player has payments+accounting
Valuation: At A$12B market cap (down from A$30B), market assigns near-zero value to Melio; any success is upside
contradicting: US$2.5B acquisition price at 8x revenue for pre-profit business; write-down risk if US growth disappoints
No independent confirmation of breakeven claims; management-sourced only
US market has been Xero's weakest geography historically; Melio may not change structural dynamics

hypotheses.title: D3: AI Disruption Re-Prices SaaS
hypotheses.statusText: Dominant — Deepening. Anthropic Claude Cited as Catalyst
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↑ Deepening; specific AI catalyst now identified
hypotheses.description: This thesis has intensified from theoretical to market-moving. The February 2026 sell-off was specifically triggered by Anthropic's Claude AI demonstrations, which the market interpreted as capable of automating core accounting workflows. The ASX IT Index fell 9.4% in a single session. Xero fell from ~A$95 to A$78.50, breaking through every prior support level. The 60% drawdown from A$194 is no longer a generic SaaS re-rating — it is the market pricing a specific, named AI threat to cloud accounting business models. The absence of churn is noted but considered a lagging indicator by the market. Price leads fundamentals; this is the market front-running a structural shift.
supporting: Market Price: Stock down 60% from A$194.21 to A$78.50 in 8 months. The most powerful evidence domain. A drawdown of this magnitude, accelerating, is not sentiment — it is repricing

AI Catalyst: Anthropic's Claude specifically cited as trigger for February 2026 ASX tech rout; AI capability demonstrations interpreted as threatening automated bookkeeping, reconciliation, and compliance
Sector-Wide: ASX IT Index fell 9.4% in one session; broad SaaS de-rating accelerating globally as AI disruption reprices growth expectations
Media & Narrative: "AI disrupts accounting" is now the dominant framing; Xero named alongside other SaaS casualties in major financial press
contradicting: Financial Statements: Churn at historic lows; no sign of customer departure. This remains the strongest counter-evidence and is independently verifiable
Broker Research: All 15 analysts rate Buy; average target A$191 (143% upside). Consensus has never been wider from price in Xero's history
Academic: Research shows AI augments accounting workflows; full automation requires regulatory compliance, judgment, and liability frameworks that don't exist
Xero's AI Response: Company planning AI monetisation for FY27; argues domain expertise, decades of data, payment rails, and 1,000+ app ecosystem create an AI moat, not vulnerability
Alternative Data: No visible churn signal in app downloads, web traffic, customer reviews, or NPS scores

hypotheses.title: D4: Competitive Displacement
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↓ No competitive share loss in any market
hypotheses.description: QuickBooks (Intuit) and MYOB take meaningful market share from Xero in core ANZ and UK markets. This thesis has weakened further: no competitor is demonstrably taking share, Intuit's growth is in tax and mid-market (not SMB cloud), and MYOB remains stagnant under private ownership. The AI disruption thesis (T3) has absorbed this hypothesis's energy — if Xero is displaced, it will be by AI-native tools, not by existing competitors.
contradicting: Competitor Data: Intuit growth concentrated in tax and mid-market; no SMB share gains against Xero
Financial Statements: Subscriber additions positive across all geographies; no share loss visible
Academic: Accounting SaaS has highest switching costs of any SaaS category (3-5 year lock-in)
Broker Research: No analyst models competitive displacement as base case; AI is the threat, not incumbents

narrative.theNarrative: The market narrative has sharpened from generic "SaaS de-rating" to a specific AI disruption thesis with a named catalyst. Anthropic's Claude AI demonstrations triggered a February 2026 ASX tech rout that collapsed the IT Index 9.4% in a single session and drove Xero through every prior support level to A$78.50 — a 60% drawdown from the A$194 high. The embedded thesis: AI will automate the core accounting workflows (bookkeeping, reconciliation, compliance) that justify Xero's subscription pricing. The counter-thesis: Xero's moat lies not in automatable tasks but in domain expertise, decades of accounting data, regulatory compliance frameworks, payment rails, and a 1,000+ app ecosystem. The market is pricing disruption; every measurable business metric says the opposite. The gap is now 145% between analyst consensus (A$191) and market price (A$78.50). One of them is catastrophically wrong.

priceImplication.label: Embedded Assumptions at A$78.50
priceImplication.content: AI disrupts core product within 2-3 years: Market prices automated bookkeeping replacing Xero's value proposition. Revenue growth decelerates sharply: Growth expected to slow from 20% toward single digits as AI alternatives emerge. Churn accelerates: Market front-running customer departures not yet visible in data. Melio write-down: US$2.5B acquisition at near-zero implied value. Multiple permanently compressed: Premium SaaS valuations never recover; cloud accounting re-rated as legacy category.

narrative.evidenceCheck: The evidence picture has become more extreme, not more resolved. Fundamental evidence is the strongest in Xero's history: Revenue +20%, ARPU +15%, Rule of 40 at 44.5%, churn at historic lows, four consecutive earnings beats, Melio ahead of plan, all 15 analysts Buy at average A$191. Market evidence is the most bearish in Xero's history: 60% drawdown, growth fund exodus, 4-5% short interest, AI disruption narrative dominant, ASX tech sector collapsing. Critically: the analyst-to-price gap of 145% is unprecedented for a profitable, growing ASX 50 company. Either consensus is uniformly blind to a paradigm shift, or the market has overshot on a narrative with zero empirical support in Xero's own metrics. This is the most contested analytical picture on the ASX.
narrative.narrativeStability: Extremely unstable. The AI disruption narrative is strengthening with each new AI capability demonstration (Anthropic Claude was the latest catalyst). It is theoretically weakened by each earnings beat — but the market has now ignored four consecutive beats. The narrative is most vulnerable to the FY26 full-year results on 14 May 2026: another strong result with no churn signal, combined with a credible AI monetisation strategy, would stretch the bear case beyond its breaking point. Conversely, any sign of subscriber deceleration or churn uptick would validate what the market has been pricing for 8 months. Xero's planned AI monetisation announcements for FY27 could also be a catalyst — if Xero positions itself as an AI beneficiary rather than victim, the narrative could flip rapidly.

evidence.intro: Ten evidence domains assessed. Fundamental evidence supports T1 (Platform Expansion) across 8 domains, but market price — itself the most powerful evidence domain — is unambiguously pricing T3 (AI Disruption). The 145% gap between analyst consensus and market price is the widest for any profitable ASX 50 company. This is the defining analytical tension.

cards.title: 1. Corporate Communications
cards.finding: CEO Sukhinder Singh Cassidy framing FY26 as "execution year" following Melio integration. 1H FY26 results: revenue NZ$1.19B (+20%), ARPU NZ$49.63 (+15%), subscriber additions on track. Management highlighted "strong unit economics" and "improving operating leverage." Melio positioned as the US go-to-market engine; early integration described as "on track." FCF margin guidance maintained. Rule of 40 at 44.5%, up from 40.1% prior year.
cards.tension: Management messaging is uniformly positive, but this is a company that paid US$2.5B for a US payments business while its own stock was falling. The tension is between genuinely strong operational metrics (which are independently verifiable in filings) and the strategic question of whether Melio was the right acquisition at the right price. The 1H numbers are strong; the Melio thesis is unproven.
cards.source: 1H FY26 Results, Nov 2025; Investor Day presentations; ASX announcements

cards.title: 2. Regulatory Filings & Financial Statements
cards.finding: FY25 full year (audited): Revenue NZ$2.10B (+22.7%). Operating expenses growing slower than revenue, demonstrating genuine operating leverage. 1H FY26: EBITDA NZ$377.9M; FCF margin 26.9%; net subscriber additions positive across all geographies. Melio acquisition funded from a mix of debt and equity; balance sheet remains manageable. No material audit qualifications. Deferred revenue growing, indicating forward visibility. Churn rate at historic lows, below pre-pandemic levels.
cards.source: XRO FY25 Annual Report; 1H FY26 statutory accounts; ASX filings

cards.title: 3. Broker Research
cards.finding: Unanimously bullish. All 15 analysts Buy or Outperform. Average target: A$191 (+143% upside). UBS Buy A$174, Citi Buy A$210, Macquarie Outperform A$228.90, Ord Minnett Buy A$200. This is the widest gap between consensus and market price in Xero's listed history. No analyst has a Sell, Underweight, or even Hold rating. Consensus FY26 revenue: NZ$2.55B (+21%). No analyst models AI-driven churn as a base case. Several have increased targets post the sell-off, calling it "sentiment-driven overshoot."
cards.tension: The gap between analyst consensus (A$191) and market price (A$78.50) is 145% — unprecedented for a profitable ASX 50 company. Either: (a) every covering analyst is uniformly blind to a paradigm shift that the market is correctly pricing; or (b) the market has overshot catastrophically in a narrative-driven selloff. The uniformity is remarkable: not a single analyst has downgraded despite a 60% decline. Either they are all wrong, or the market is.
cards.source: UBS, Citi, Macquarie, Ord Minnett, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley consensus; Feb 2026 updates

cards.title: 4. Competitor Disclosures
cards.finding: Intuit (QuickBooks): Reported strong results but growth is concentrated in tax and mid-market, not SMB cloud accounting. Intuit's ARPU growth primarily from pricing, not subscriber additions. MYOB: Private, limited disclosure. Australian market share stable but not growing. FreshBooks, Wave: Niche players, no material market share shifts. Key insight: no competitor is demonstrably taking share from Xero in its core ANZ and UK markets.
cards.source: Intuit Q2 FY26 earnings; MYOB industry data; market share surveys

cards.title: 5. Economic Data
cards.finding: SMB formation rates mixed globally. Australian new business registrations stable. UK SMB environment constrained by higher interest rates but showing signs of improvement. US SMB formation elevated post-COVID but normalising. Cloud accounting penetration still below 50% in all major markets, suggesting significant runway remains. Digital transformation of SMB financial management is a secular trend, not a cyclical one.
cards.source: ABS, ONS, US Census Bureau; industry cloud adoption surveys

cards.title: 6. Alternative Data
cards.finding: App downloads: Xero mobile app downloads stable across App Store and Google Play. No sign of deceleration or competitive displacement. Web traffic: Xero.com traffic stable to slightly growing. Job postings: Xero hiring activity consistent with growth company profile; significant engineering and product roles. NPS / reviews: Customer satisfaction scores stable. No visible churn acceleration in third-party data.
cards.source: App Annie/Sensor Tower data; SimilarWeb; LinkedIn job postings; G2/Capterra reviews

cards.title: 7. Academic Research
cards.finding: SaaS switching costs research: Published studies on enterprise and SMB SaaS platforms consistently find that accounting software has among the highest switching costs of any SaaS category. Data migration costs, workflow re-training, and integration complexity create 3-5 year lock-in cycles. AI impact research: Current AI capabilities augment rather than replace accounting workflows; full automation of SMB accounting remains beyond near-term AI capability due to regulatory, compliance, and judgment requirements.
cards.source: Published SaaS economics research; AI capability assessments; technology adoption studies

cards.title: 8. Media & Social
cards.finding: AI panic dominates all financial media. The February 2026 sell-off was triggered by Anthropic's Claude AI demonstrations, which financial press framed as directly threatening cloud accounting workflows. Headlines: "Xero caught in AI crosshairs," "SaaS stocks hammered as AI reality bites," "ASX tech bloodbath: 9.4% single-session collapse." Social sentiment on investment forums overwhelmingly bearish. The narrative has shifted from generic "AI disrupts SaaS" to specific: "Claude can do bookkeeping, reconciliation, and compliance — why pay for Xero?" No credible reporting of actual churn or customer departure exists. The narrative is ahead of the evidence by the widest margin for any ASX company.
cards.tension: The media narrative is the primary driver of the sell-off, yet it rests on zero empirical evidence of customer impact. This is not unprecedented — market narratives routinely front-run fundamentals — but the magnitude of the gap between narrative (catastrophic disruption) and evidence (historic low churn, 20% growth) is exceptional.

tags.text: Strongly Supports T3 (AI narrative now has named catalyst)

cards.source: Australian Financial Review; Reuters; Bloomberg; tech press; Anthropic Claude launch coverage; Feb 2026

cards.title: 9. Leadership & Governance
cards.finding: Strong board, still-proving CEO. Sukhinder Singh Cassidy took the CEO role in February 2023, previously serving as Board Chair. Her background is US tech (Google, StubHub) rather than accounting software, which aligns with Xero's platform expansion strategy but remains unproven at this scale. The A$2.95B Melio acquisition was her defining strategic bet. Chairman David Thodey is one of Australia's most respected corporate leaders (Telstra transformation, CSIRO Chair). Board quality is high: deep SaaS, financial services, and technology expertise across directors. Key strength: governance structures are institutional-grade with clear committee oversight. Key risk: the Melio acquisition price (8x revenue for a pre-profit business) will define Singh Cassidy's tenure. If Melio delivers, she is vindicated; if not, the board may face pressure.

rows: Google VP; StubHub CEO; theBoardlist founder

cards.source: XRO Annual Report FY25; ASX announcements; board biographical disclosures

cards.title: 10. Ownership & Capital Flows
cards.finding: Growth fund exodus accelerating; short interest elevated. The register continues to rotate: active growth managers (Hyperion reduced from ~6% to ~4.5%, Baillie Gifford reduced) selling into the decline. At A$78.50, the stock is now below the cost basis of most institutional holders who bought in the last 3 years. Short interest remains elevated at ~4-5% of shares outstanding, among the highest for an ASX 50 company, reflecting active bearish bets. Passive holders (Vanguard, BlackRock, State Street) are steady, providing an index-weight floor. No discretionary insider buying at current levels, which is notable given management's bullish public commentary. The marginal buyer must be a deep-value or contrarian investor, not the growth funds who have been liquidating.
cards.source: ASX substantial holder notices; ASIC short position reports; NZX disclosures; annual report top-20

discriminators.intro: Four data points carry high diagnosticity. The AI disruption thesis now has a named catalyst (Anthropic Claude), but still zero empirical evidence in Xero's metrics. The next 3 months will discriminate between narrative and reality.

rows.evidence: FY26 Full Year Results (14 May 2026). Revenue growth ≥18% + no churn = T3 remains evidence-free. Growth <15% or churn uptick = T3 gains first empirical support.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (execution continues despite narrative) vs T3 (AI disruption reaching fundamentals)
rows.currentReading: On track at +20%; churn at historic lows

rows.evidence: Xero AI Monetisation Strategy (FY27 roadmap). If Xero positions AI as revenue enhancer, narrative flips. If silent, market narrative dominates.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (Xero as AI beneficiary) vs T3 (Xero as AI victim)
rows.currentReading: FY27 AI strategy announced but not detailed

rows.evidence: Melio Breakeven Confirmation (H2 FY28). Tracking 6-12 months ahead of plan; confirmation would validate US$2.5B acquisition.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T2 (strategic success) vs T2 failure (write-down risk)

rows.evidence: Churn Rate in FY26 Full Year. Any uptick would be the first empirical signal of AI disruption. Historic lows maintained = T3 remains purely narrative.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (platform sticky; AI not displacing) vs T3 (AI displacement beginning)

discriminators.nonDiscriminating: "Stock down 60%" (price is the question, not the answer) • "Anthropic Claude can do bookkeeping" (capability demonstration is not adoption evidence; no churn, no switching) • "P/E of 41.3x looks expensive" (irrelevant for 20% growth SaaS; FCF margin and Rule of 40 are correct metrics) • "Melio cost US$2.5B" (acquisition price does not determine value; breakeven trajectory does)

tripwires.intro: Four revision conditions. The AI disruption thesis now has a named catalyst but zero empirical evidence. The next 3 months will determine whether narrative or fundamentals prevail.

cards.name: FY26 Full Year Results — The Decisive Test

conditions.if: If revenue growth ≥18%, Rule of 40 ≥42, churn at/below historic lows
conditions.then: T1 strengthens decisively. Fifth consecutive beat. T3 stretched to breaking point. Market re-rating catalyst.

conditions.if: If revenue growth <15% or churn uptick visible
conditions.then: T3 gains first empirical evidence. Narrative validated. Further de-rating likely.

cards.source: Source: ASX announcement, FY26 Annual Report, 14 May 2026

cards.name: Xero AI Monetisation Strategy

conditions.if: If Xero articulates credible AI-native features that increase ARPU and deepen moat
conditions.then: Narrative flips: Xero as AI beneficiary, not victim. T3 weakens materially. Re-rating catalyst.

conditions.if: If AI strategy is vague or absent; no product differentiation from generic AI tools
conditions.then: T3 narrative confirmed. Market validated in pricing AI displacement.

cards.source: Source: Xero Investor Day; FY27 product roadmap; management presentations

cards.name: Melio Breakeven Confirmation

conditions.if: If Melio tracking to H2 FY28 breakeven confirmed with metrics
conditions.then: T2 strengthens. US$2.5B acquisition proving strategic. Upside optionality crystallises.

conditions.if: If Melio timeline slips or integration issues emerge
conditions.then: T2 weakens. Write-down risk increases. Market scepticism validated.

cards.source: Source: FY26 results; management commentary; investor presentations

cards.name: Churn Rate — The Empirical Acid Test

conditions.if: If churn remains at historic lows
conditions.then: T3 remains evidence-free. 60% sell-off rests entirely on narrative, not data.

conditions.if: If churn increases by >50bp in any period
conditions.then: T3 gains first empirical evidence. Would need to distinguish AI-driven vs macro-driven churn.

cards.source: Source: Xero 1H/FY results; third-party app/web data; customer surveys

couldntAssess: Melio integration metrics: Management says "ahead of plan" for H2 FY28 breakeven, but no independent confirmation of revenue contribution, cross-sell rates, or US subscriber unit economics.

AI disruption timeline: Anthropic Claude was cited as the specific catalyst, but no analysis quantifies when or whether AI capabilities translate to actual accounting software displacement. The gap between capability demonstration and customer switching is unknown.

AI monetisation upside: Xero plans FY27 AI strategy but details are unavailable. If Xero successfully monetises AI (higher ARPU, deeper moat), the current thesis inverts entirely — from victim to beneficiary. Cannot assess without product details.

Institutional positioning: True institutional conviction levels are lagged. Growth fund selling (Hyperion, Baillie Gifford) is visible but value fund accumulation at current levels is not yet discernible from public register data.
gaps.analyticalLimitations: Hypothesis survival scores (T1: 40%, T2: 35%, T3: 55%, T4: 15%) reflect editorial assessment updated post-February 2026 sell-off. T3 (AI Disruption) is scored dominant because the market price — the most powerful evidence signal — has deepened from -55% to -60% with a specific named catalyst (Anthropic Claude). However, fundamental evidence across 8 of 10 domains supports T1 (Platform Expansion). T2 (Melio) strengthened on ahead-of-plan breakeven. T4 weakened further on zero competitive displacement evidence. The 145% gap between analyst consensus (A$191) and market price (A$78.50) is unprecedented for a profitable ASX 50 company. We present this tension honestly. The judgment remains yours.

footer.disclaimer: This report does not constitute personal financial advice. Continuum Intelligence synthesises cross-domain evidence using the Analysis of Competing Hypotheses (ACH) methodology. All factual claims are sourced from ASX filings, company accounts, broker consensus data, and publicly available information. This report does not contain buy, sell, or hold recommendations, price targets, or valuation models.

resistance.method: Prior support turned resistance (Jan 2026 breakdown level)

priorSpikes.context: AI panic sell-off; ASX IT Index -9.4%; break below A$100
Anthropic Claude catalyst; new 52-week low A$77.71; capitulation volume

inflectionPoints.event: Death cross formed; 50-day MA crosses below 200-day MA
AI panic: ASX IT Index -9.4%; Anthropic Claude cited as catalyst; break below A$100
New 52-week low; volume 4.8x avg; -60% from high; capitulation characteristics
